messageBody:
Matthew Pope wrote:

> Mike,
> I meant this as an adjuct to writing an automated test. When the automated test
> fails, rather than using the debugger, carefully putting in Log statements is putting
> in 'debug-check-state' at important places, that the maintenance programmer can later
> access. I agree that these need to be sometimes purged if they pollute the code to
> much. Only the most important ones are left in.
> Matthew
>

Very well. I agree that debug statements in limited form serve a useful purpose. For
example, perhaps a user would prefer to enable a category of debug statements to output
the utilization of a pool of objects, for example. However, if these debug statements
are used to assert conditions, then I'd remove the statements in favor of an assertion
facility (e.g. automated tests). It's just my style...

Mike
